summary: *** references in 9
See that God objected to their self-confidence, saying their pride had deceived them.
God swept away safety and security, despite there confidence. (Home, treasures, treaties, wise and mighty men.)
Obvious parallels to us here in the US.
How can we not be deceived by our own pride?
How can we not make the same mistake as Edom.
1). No self-confidence, (Proverbs 3, Joshua 1, Psalm 121)
==== Not in some of my ways, all of my ways.
==== Being strong and courageous, because I know the Lord is on my side.
2). Grave mistake to believe in our efforts result in our safety and security. (James 4, Luke 12)
==== My natural tendency is to seek protection from the world through natural means. (good job, safe neighborhood, secure passwords,...
==== My mistake is that I see these as more than just tools, and don't acknowledge God for my safety.
==== If I think I am somehow clever and make my posessions impregnable, I am making Edom's mistake, not acknowledging perfect giver.
==== Edom being stripped bare Jer 49 'I have uncovered his hiding places' => wherever you might be hiding your valuables: they are vunerable
==== Like the man in James 4, or the Rich fool in Luke 12.
==== I'm not saying we should test God by not locking our doors, but grab hold of the truth that he is our safety and security.
3). It is for our own good. (James 4:6, 1 Peter)
==== Don't want to be put in a position of being opposed by God.
==== Grades of a student. (Acknowledge Him)
==== Good at work. (Acknowledge Him)
==== Don't take credit for accomplishments
Transition: Edom's transgression is Pride.

introduction: Transition: Edom's transgression: Gloating over Israel's demise.
Might ask why is this wrong?
Israel and Edom were for the most part enemies.
Picture layed out in scripture: By God's choice, Jacob was the choosen twin, loved and blessed. But the nation didn't obey God, and they were punished for it.
Open verse 11, 14.
summary: Lay it bare, Lay it Bare was not the response that God desired from Edom.
A better response would have been love your neighbor as yourself: not to gloat, to show mercy and pity on their brother nation, helping those fleeing the violence.
How can we apply this today?
One could say this was a unique situation.
Same picture is layed out in scripture for us as followers of Christ, we are choosen, loved and blessed.
When I see other Christians stumble, how do I respond?
What are my secret thoughts I can gloat:
==== Someone I don't know personally: I knew it, they were just pretending, what a hypocrite.
==== Someone I know personally: If they would just do things the right way: read their Bible and pray, they wouldn't have this issue.
In my heart I'm making the same mistake as Edom, gloating and not showing mercy.
Have to be careful with my secret thoughts, that I show mercy.
Its natural to ask the questions: Why did this happen to them?, or What can I learn so that doesn't happen to me?
Although it is natural to ask these questions, but I'm not sure that is always the best or even necessary.
Late 90s, Teacher HIV
Jesus addresses this issue in Luke 13.
Far more important to repent, then the need to know why something bad happened to someone.
